name: Alphatronic PC models P3 / P4
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with separated editing and numeric keyboard
description:
These two computers (P3 and P4) are professional systems conceived by Triumph-Adler. There are based on 8085A CPU and have 64k RAM.

They used the MOS operating system but are also CP/M compatible. There were delivered with CP/M, UCSD-P System and Holland Automation on disks.

The difference between the two models is that the P3 is equiped with two 5''1/4 (785 kb formated) floppy-drives, whereas the P4 has one floppy and one hard-disk (5 Mb).

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad uses actors, except for IMSAI's Finance Director Hersch Mandelman as the "Milk Man".</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, APRIL 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computer World magazine.<br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> It's an extraordinarily powerful machine which offers word-processing, spreadsheet, and a set of time and data-management tools in a single, highly porlable package.<br> At £199.95. the Z88 is supplied with 32K resident RAM. Extra 32K costs under £20, extra 128K under £50!<br> And heavy users Will be able to expand the RAM to an astonishing 3 Mbytes, using plug-in RAM cartridges.<br> For printing text or data, the Z88 connects direcly to most popular RS232 compatible printers, while for permanent storage the Z88 employs removable solid state EPROM cartridges - no tape to break, no delicate disc to damage.<br> Though the Z88 is a powerful, full facility, self-contained computer, it also acts as an extension of an office micro, connecting directly to allow exchange of text or data.<br> For every personal computer user, the Z88 offers a comprehensive specification in a package of unparalleled portability.</font>  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-1200 (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The industry said it couldn't be done. You can't put a hard disk in a portable PC, make it powerful and keep it under 11 lbs.<br> Well, with this that challenge in mind, we immediately went to work to prove them wrong, presenting the result, the new T1200... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> THINKJET ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>August 1985</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-3100 (FEB. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, working away from your office meant baving to settle for lesser computers or no computer at all.<br> Toshiba ends that compromise. The T3100 delivers the power of an IBM PC AT in a lean, 15-pound computer that you can take with you. With a full-sized keyboard and advanced gas plasma display that give you equal comfort and clarity on your desk or on the road <br><br> Don't let its size fool you.<br> Though the T3100 is no bigger than many laptop computers, it offers the power of a full function IBM compatible desktop AT system. You get the speed and ease of a built-in hard disk, communications and expansion options, and more-including dual-voltage power that lets you plug in and go to work just about anywhere in the world.</font>  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad is unique in that it features professional actors and IMSAI employees.  <p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> During Jacquard's early years, as a "system house", the company developed communications and peripheral devices that were not available from any other sources. Some of these are still available only from Jacquard. <br><br> Through these devices, Jacquard acquired hardware design and production skills, thus becoming experienced in integrating 'pieces' into systems that worked, and worked well. <br><br> These years of experience enabled Jacquard to design the first truly affordable and multi-functional small business system - the Jacquard Videocomputer... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> With NEC's PC-8800 personal computer, you don't have to ask yourself which comes first, the hardware or the software.<br> It's designed to be uncompromising in both areas. So you come first. In the office or at home.<br> The hardware gives you your choice of 8-bit or 16-bit processors, 5 1/4" or 8" disk drives and standard green or high resolution color monitor.<br> The software includes advanced, user friendly programs for all types of banking, accounting and business management. Plus free WordStar word processing, and MailMerge, Multiplan spread sheet, BASIC (two versions), and CP/M... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>''For less than 2000 francs, offer yourself the future''  ...yes</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Opening to the computers universe.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each picture represents a customers target. Three of them are well known: Home/entertainement,  office and educational uses. A fourth one is added for the first time, the senior citizens. Epson thought the QX-10 was user-friendly enough to be used by retired people.   </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1982 HEATHKIT CENTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Yannick Noah Tennis cartridge. The game is only called "Grand Slam Tennis" on the Emerson Arcadia 2001, but in France was marketed with the most famous french tennis player's name, Yannick Noah.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thomson, you make me micro"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60, to show that the BIT-60 is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really  working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>English advert for the 86A model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> <b>The All-Purpose System</b> <br><br> The MTX Series is a new departure in micro-computer technology. Whether your needs as a user ore for personal programming, games playing, scientific or process control, educational or business use the MTX Series is already capable or very easily adoptable to almost every application. Glance through the standard features below - you'll see what we mean.<br><br> <b>Software</b><br> The MTX's 24K ROM contains several languages and routines which enable the novice or the experienced programmer to make full use of the machine. Standard languages are MTX BASIC, MTX LOGO commands, NODDY. ROM routines include on ASSSEMBLER/DISASSEMBLER with screen display of the Z80 CPU registers, memory and program, which can be manipulated from the keyboard. Machine code programs can be stepped through one instruction at a time, and easily called from within BASIC programs. A further feature is the Virtual Screen facility which enables the programmer to split the screen into a maximum of eight sections to work independently whilst maIntaining all full screen facilities. Pascal is available as on add-on ROM pock.<br><br> <b>Hardware - 32K RAM on the MTX500. 64K on the MTX512.</b><br> The MTX500 has 32K of user RAM as standard (64K on the 512), expandable to 512K plus 16K of video RAM, controlled by a separate Video Processor. Sixteen colours, 40 column text, 256 x 192 high resolution graphics with all sixteen colours available, and 32 easily moveable user defined graphics characters (Sprites) combine to make effective screen displays quick and simple to achieve. Standard outputs are centronics printer port, two ioystick ports, an uncommitted I/O port, 2400 Baud Cassette port, separate TV and Video Monitor ports, 4 channel sound with hifi output plus a dedicated cartridge port. Other standard features include the Z80A processor runnIng at 4MHz, real time clock, full moving key keyboard with 79 keys including eight 2-function keys and separate numeric pad.<br><br> <b>The Disc Based Computers from Memotech.</b> Designed to use the full power of the MTX computers the FDX and HDX make perfect busIness systems at prices which make perfect business sense. Both feature the CP/M operating system, giving Instant access to a wide range of proven application software. Available in October these feature:<br> • Full Western Digital floppy dIsc controller set with SASI interface for 4 drives, CP/M types 0 - 13.<br> • minimal latency, very high data transfer rates<br> • optional Colour 80 Column Board<br> • optional SilIcon Discs (1/4 Mb) which dramatically Increase the efficiency of 8 bit software to those of 16/32 bit software; increases life and reliability of mechanical drive<br> • permits single disc CP/M operation<br><br> <b>FDX Floppy Disc System</b><br> 1 or 2 5 1/4" Qume drives 500K unformatted, 347K formatted.<br> <b>HDX- Hard Disc System</b><br> 5 1/4" Qume drive, 500K unformatted, 347K formatted, 5 1/4" Winchester which may be 5, 10, or 20 Mb.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #3 (1979) </strong></font><br><blockquote>From Playboy December 1979.  <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Peathead</b></p></blockquote>

builtInGames: Model P3 : 2 x 5''1/4 disk-drives (785kb each), double-sided, double densityModel P4 : 1 x 5''1/4 disk-drive and 1 x Hard-disk (5Mb)
